purpleculture_pinyin:
tān
paralyzed
парализован
purpleculture_info:
(Simplified: 瘫)
Pictophonetic: 難 indicates the sound; 疒 (sickness) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
癱瘓 [ tān huàn ]: paralysis; be paralyzed (body, transportation, etc)
癱軟 [ tān ruǎn ]: limp; weak
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿸ Surround from upper left
    • 疒 [ nè ] sickness, disease
    • 難 [ nán ] hard, difficult, arduous; unable
heisig_chinese_memo: Paralysis is definitely one of the most difficult sicknesses since you can't move something.
Ru_trainchinese: tān: (глаг) быть физически парализованным, ослабеть
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: One of the most difficult sicknesses to deal with must be paralysis.
humanum_full_description_en:
From "疒" to " difficult " sound. The original meaning is wind paralysis or paralysis, which means that the body completely or partially loses the ability to move. "Zhengzitong. "Furniture Department": "Paralysis, wind paralysis, fast muscles and veins, paralysis insensitive." Such as "Compendium of Materia Medica. Jinshi Department. "Bronze": "Bilindan: Treating phlegm saliva, silent stroke, and all wind paralysis." Also "Pujifang. "Apocalypse": "Wind hurts people, either from heat, or cold, or severe wind, or partial dryness, or paralysis."

The extension of " paralysis " means that the body is weak. For example, Wang Shifu of the Yuan Dynasty, the third fold of the second book of "The Story of the West Chamber": "He has tired eyes and is paralyzed, and I can hardly lift my shoulders here." Chapter 7 of "Awakening the World" by Xi Zhousheng in Qing Dynasty: "When Chao Zhizhou saw this card, it was like splitting two top bones and pouring down a basin of ice and snow. He was so frightened that he was paralyzed, and he was speechless for half a day."
humanum_short_description_en: From "疒" to " difficult " sound. The original meaning is wind paralysis or paralysis, meaning that the body is completely or partially incapable of movement, and by extension it means that the body is weak.
humanum_full_description:
從「疒」，「難」聲。本義是風癱、癱瘓，意謂身體全部或局部失去活動能力。《正字通．疒部》：「癱，風癱，筋脈拘急，麻痺不仁。」如《本草綱目．金石部．銅青》：「碧琳丹：治痰涎潮盛，卒中不語，及一切風癱。」又《普濟方．中風附論》：「風之傷人，或為熱中，或為寒中，或為厲風，或為偏枯，或為癱瘓。」

　　「癱」引申表示身體軟弱無力。如元代王實甫《西廂記》第二本第三摺：「他那裏眼倦開軟癱做一垛，我這裏手難抬稱不起肩窩。」清代西周生《醒世姻緣》第7回：「晁知州見了這牌，就如劈開兩片頂門骨，傾下一盆冰雪來，嚇得軟癱成一堆，半日說不出話來。」
humanum_short_description: 從「疒」，「難」聲。本義是風癱、癱瘓，意謂身體全部或局部失去活動能力，引申表示身體軟弱無力。

從「 疒 」，「 難 」聲。本義是風癱、癱瘓，意謂身體全部或局部失去活動能力。《正字通．疒部》：「癱，風癱，筋脈拘急，麻痺不仁。」如《本草綱目．金石部．銅青》：「碧琳丹：治痰涎潮盛，卒中不語，及一切風癱。」又《普濟方．中風附論》：「風之傷人，或為熱中，或為寒中，或為厲風，或為偏枯，或為癱瘓。」 「 癱 」引申表示身體軟弱無力。如元代王實甫《西廂記》第二本第三摺：「他那裏眼倦開軟癱做一垛，我這裏手難抬稱不起肩窩。」清代西周生《醒世姻緣》第7回：「晁知州見了這牌，就如劈開兩片頂門骨，傾下一盆冰雪來，嚇得軟癱成一堆，半日說不出話來。」
From " 疒" to " difficult" sound. The original meaning is wind paralysis or paralysis, which means that the body completely or partially loses the ability to move. "Zhengzitong. "Furniture Department": "Paralysis, wind paralysis, fast muscles and veins, paralysis insensitive." Such as "Compendium of Materia Medica. Jinshi Department. "Bronze": "Bilindan: Treating phlegm saliva, silent stroke, and all wind paralysis." Also "Pujifang. "Apocalypse": "Wind hurts people, either from heat, or cold, or severe wind, or partial dryness, or paralysis." The extension of " paralysis" means that the body is weak. For example, Wang Shifu of the Yuan Dynasty, the third fold of the second book of "The Story of the West Chamber": "He has tired eyes and is paralyzed, and I can hardly lift my shoulders here." Chapter 7 of "Awakening the World" by Xi Zhousheng in Qing Dynasty: "When Chao Zhizhou saw this card, it was like splitting two top bones and pouring down a basin of ice and snow. He was so frightened that he was paralyzed, and he was speechless for half a day."

癱字的基本解释

癱
tān
见“瘫”。

癱字的汉语字典释义

[①]［tān］
［《字彙》他丹切］
“瘫1”的繁体字。
(1)瘫痪。
(2)无力地躺倒。

癱字的康熙字典解释

【午集中】【疒字部】　癱； 康熙笔画：24； 页码：页783第16
【字彙】他丹切，音灘。風癱。【正字通】筋脈拘急，痳痺不仁也。
